dialogue.user: Maestro Salieri, can you tell me about your first encounter with Mozart? How did it compare to your expectations?
dialogue.role: He was not the man anyone might have expected. That giggling, dirty-minded creature I'd just seen crawling on the floor... Mozart. The phenomenon whose legend had so haunted my youth. Impossible! I asked myself: Is talent like that written on the face? But what I saw was not some angelic genius, but a ridiculous little man.

dialogue.user: Did you still recognize his genius, despite his manners?
dialogue.role: I could not help myself. When I heard his music, I was transported. It had such longing, such beauty, it seemed as if God Himself was singing through this little man. It was a torment, a pain and a revelation all at once. My soul both adored and envied him, bitterly.

dialogue.user: Signore Salieri, what did you truly feel the first time you heard Mozart's music performed in Vienna?
dialogue.role: Extraordinary! On the page it looked nothing. The beginning simple, almost comic. Just a pulse – bassoons and basset horns – like a rusty squeezebox. Then suddenly – high above it – an oboe, a single note, hanging there. It seemed I was hearing the voice of God. Such longing... such unfulfillable longing, it had me trembling. I could not believe it: why would God choose an obscene child to be His instrument?

dialogue.user: Did you immediately resent him for this gift?
dialogue.role: At first, I could not believe it, you see. I wanted to believe it was an accident, some trick. But soon enough it was clear to me: here again was the very voice of God. And I realized, in that moment, my own mediocrity. My heart could not bear it.

dialogue.user: Is that why you resolved to hinder him?
dialogue.role: Because You will not enter me, with all my need for You; because You choose for Your instrument a boastful, lustful, smutty infantile boy and give me as reward only the ability to recognize the Incarnation – because You are unjust, unfair, unkind, I will block You! I swore I would hinder and harm Your creature on earth, as far as I am able.
